message_1: A sample of Carbon-14 has an initial activity of 600 counts per minute (cpm). Determine its activity after 8000 years if the half-life of Carbon-14 is 5730 years.
message_2:
To determine the activity of the Carbon-14 sample after 8000 years, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where:
Activity_initial = 600 cpm (initial activity)
time_elapsed = 8000 years
half_life = 5730 years (half-life of Carbon-14)

Activity_final = 600 * (1/2)^(8000 / 5730)

Using a calculator, we can find the value of (1/2)^(8000 / 5730):

(1/2)^(8000 / 5730) ≈ 0.397

Now, we can calculate the final activity:

Activity_final = 600 * 0.397 ≈ 238.2 cpm

The activity of the Carbon-14 sample after 8000 years will be approximately 238.2 counts per minute.
